body:
The current documentation stems mostly from a time when Pure Python Mode wasn't even being thought of and aims to present the special `cdef` syntax that Cython uses. The Pure Python Syntax is only presented on the [pure Python tutorial page](http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html).

Today, more and more new users come from a Python background that uses type annotations. We should accommodate them by presenting both syntax variants hand in hand throughout the documentation.

If you want to help out, please do the following:

1) Grab a documentation page and duplicate the code examples into separate files, inlcuding the Pure Python variant *before* the `cdef` variant with `literalinclude`. See 
This currently excludes the pages that refer to the integration of external C or C++ code, since some of the required language features are not available in Pure Python code/mode (and this should be mentioned in those places).

For example, a file `add1.pyx`:
```cython
cdef int add1(int x) except -1:
    return x + 1
```
should be accompanied by a file `add1.py`:
```cython
@cython.exceptval(-1)
def add1(x: cython.int):
    return x + 1
```

2) Read the surrounding text to see if there is anything that refers to the specific syntax constructs. Make sure everything is well explained to the readers so that they can easily understand the two examples.

3) Put a paragraph near the top of the page to show a reference to `import cython` and briefly explain the difference between the two syntax variants:
```
.. include::
    ../two-syntax-variants-used
```
This includes the following text:
```
This page uses two different syntax variants: the Cython specific ``cdef`` syntax
and static Cython type declarations in :ref:`pure Python code <pep484_type_annotations>`,
following `PEP-484 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/>`_ type hints
and `PEP 526 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0526/>`_ variable annotations.
To make good use of the latter, including C data types etc., you need
the special ``cython`` module, which you can import with

.. code-block: python

      import cython

in the Python module that you want to compile.
```

Don't forget to link back to this issue in any PRs that you submit.

EDIT: Decisions/approaches taken further down:

- use different file extensions for the two variants: `some_example.py` and `some_example.pyx`
- present both in tabs to make it easy to switch between them
- present the Python syntax variant tab before (left of) the Cython syntax, as the first will eventually become preferable
- keep both source files aligned line by line to highlight the differences on tab switches
- run the .py variant also through Python for syntax/sanity checking (find a way to deal with pure Python cimports)
- automatically add `import cython` to the .py test files in `runtests.py` to avoid having to repeat it in all examples that need it
- explicitly write `import cython` in test examples that are long enough (and need it), especially if they use future imports or directive comments
- see https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860123077 for further conventions

List of files to consider:


- [Getting Started](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/index.html) (#4283)
    - [x] [Building Cython code](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/build.html)
    - [x] [Faster code via static typing](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/cythonize.html)
- [Tutorials](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/index.html)
    - [x] [Basic Tutorial](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/cython_tutorial.html) (#4226)
    - [x] [Calling C functions](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/external.html) (#4247)
    - [ ] [Using C libraries](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/clibraries.html) (#4294)
    - [x] [Extension types (aka. cdef classes)](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/cdef_classes.html) (#4232)
    - [ ] [pxd files](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pxd_files.html)
    - [ ] [Profiling](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/profiling_tutorial.html)
    - [ ] [Unicode and passing strings](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/strings.html)
    - [ ] [Memory Allocation](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/memory_allocation.html)
    - [ ] [Embedding Cython modules in C/C++ applications](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/embedding.html)
    - [ ] [Pure Python Mode](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html)
    - [ ] [Working with NumPy](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/numpy.html)
    - [ ] [Working with Python arrays](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/array.html)
- [Users Guide](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/index.html)
    - [ ] [Language Basics](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/language_basics.html) (#4242)
    - [ ] [Extension Types](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/extension_types.html)
    - [ ] [Special Methods of Extension Types](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/special_methods.html)
    - [ ] [Sharing Declarations Between Cython Modules](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/sharing_declarations.html)
    - [ ] [Interfacing with External C Code](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html)
    - [ ] [Source Files and Compilation](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html)
    - [ ] [Early Binding for Speed](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/early_binding_for_speed.html)
    - [ ] [Using C++ in Cython](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/wrapping_CPlusPlus.html)
    - [ ] [Fused Types (Templates)](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/fusedtypes.html)
    - [ ] [Migrating from Cython 0.29 to 3.0](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/migrating_to_cy30.html)
    - [ ] [Differences between Cython and Pyrex](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/pyrex_differences.html)
    - [ ] [Typed Memoryviews](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/memoryviews.html)
    - [ ] [Implementing the buffer protocol](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/buffer.html)
    - [ ] [Using Parallelism](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/parallelism.html)
    - [ ] [Cython for NumPy users](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/numpy_tutorial.html)

comment_data.body: And (where possible) use annotations over `@cython.declare` - right?

> And (where possible) use annotations over `@cython.declare` - right?

Absolutely. The goal is to use the least intrusive and most readable way to get the same effect as with the original syntax.
Would it be worth it to maybe create a modified/custom directive for this, so that you could toggle between the two code samples - like a tabbed code block or a toggle at the top of the page?

Tabbed code block seems like a very good idea to me - it lets us keep the examples short and to the point while still letting us show both syntaxes.

Obviously someone has to implement it...

There is a sphinx-tabs extension that supports [code tabs](https://sphinx-tabs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#code-tabs) extension that support syntax highlighting and seems to even synchronize the tabs on the page

In some situations, a supplementary pxd file can be used to provide type information, with little-to-no modifications on the original py file. Given the pros and cons associated with this approach, how much should the documentation reflect this?

`.pxd` files use Cython syntax. They are a subset of the language, basically. I think it's enough to describe this possibility in one place (that's currently the `pure` page) and otherwise leave them out when describing the language. It doesn't add anything there.

> Put the (proposed) following paragraph near the top of the page to show a reference to import cython and briefly explain the difference between the two syntax variants:

I think that the paragraph above that you proposed should point to the document about [Pure Python Mode](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html).
I think PR-s can cover one page or several. It is hardly worth expecting PR with the transformation of entire documentation.
Also, is there any progress on this issue? I can start working on this.

Yes - it's absolutely fine to do smaller PRs for a single page (or even some of a page).

I don't think anyone has done anything on this so feel free to make a start if you're interested.
Yeah no all I've done so far is taken a look at the plugin referenced above. The codeblocks I did find was in files though, so this will essentially double most of the files in the documentation.
To know for sure if `i: cython.int` will work like `cython.declare(i=cython.int)`?

> To know for sure if `i: cython.int` will work like `cython.declare(i=cython.int)`?

It seems that this is not the case, are there any plans to implement this? It seems to me that it is more pythonic.
Take a look at [Pure Python - PEP484 Type Annotations](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#pep-484-type-annotations).

> > To know for sure if `i: cython.int` will work like `cython.declare(i=cython.int)`?
> 
> It seems that this is not the case, are there any plans to implement this? It seems to me that it is more pythonic.

It should do (with the `annotation_typing` directive on, which it is by default). It may need one of the Cython 3 alpha versions to work fully (I'm not sure exactly when it was enabled)

> It may need one of the Cython 3 alpha versions to work fully (I'm not sure exactly when it was enabled)

This was partially added in 0.27 and I'm going to create an issue where I will report on the rest of the unimplemented part.
I suggest using this issue for coordination and PRs (any size) for the changes.

> The codeblocks I did find was in files though, so this will essentially double most of the files in the documentation.

That suggests to me that we should have a naming convention for the example files (which are compiled as part of our test suite). Maybe with suffixes like `_cy` and `_py` in the file name for the two syntax variants? I'd rather not leave the distinction to the file extension (.pyx vs. .py).

> > The codeblocks I did find was in files though, so this will essentially double most of the files in the documentation.
> 
> That suggests to me that we should have a naming convention for the example files (which are compiled as part of our test suite). Maybe with suffixes like `_cy` and `_py` in the file name for the two syntax variants? I'd rather not leave the distinction to the file extension (.pyx vs. .py).

Yeah look at the [source](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_sources/src/tutorial/pure.rst.txt), the documentation uses `literalinclude`: 
```
.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/tutorial/pure/A.py
```
So having `A_cy.py` and `A_py.py`?

I think instead one file should be used (this is easier for beginners) and then we could use [the lines option](https://devopstutodoc.readthedocs.io/en/stable/documentation/doc_generators/sphinx/rest_sphinx/code/literalinclude/literalinclude.html#lines-xxx).

> I think instead one file should be used (this is easier for beginners) and then we could use [the lines option](https://devopstutodoc.readthedocs.io/en/stable/documentation/doc_generators/sphinx/rest_sphinx/code/literalinclude/literalinclude.html#lines-xxx).

The files in the documentation are run in the test suite. This is good because it at least confirms that the code compiles. If you put both versions in a single file then it most likely wouldn't compile (because the names would conflict)

> > I think instead one file should be used (this is easier for beginners) and then we could use [the lines option](https://devopstutodoc.readthedocs.io/en/stable/documentation/doc_generators/sphinx/rest_sphinx/code/literalinclude/literalinclude.html#lines-xxx).
> 
> The files in the documentation are run in the test suite. This is good because it at least confirms that the code compiles. If you put both versions in a single file then it most likely wouldn't compile (because the names would conflict)

No they will compile, it will just shadow the names. You're right in that this may be a pretty big downside though and somewhat unwanted.

There is a suggestion: use `:caption: <filename>` instead of ```:file: `<filename>`:```
caption
![caption](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121610020-c1601180-ca5d-11eb-9498-e26235238cca.png)

file
![file](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121610104-ef455600-ca5d-11eb-9d58-8d1a602c2216.png)
If you agree that `caption` will improve the documentation, then I can make an issue and maybe start working on a PR.
Seems to be a relatively simple task.

> Maybe with suffixes like `_cy` and `_py`

It seems to me that `_c` and` _p` would be enough.

> > Maybe with suffixes like `_cy` and `_py`
> 
> It seems to me that `_c` and` _p` would be enough.

Although, using the prime tutorial as an example, there is `primes.pyx`, `primes_cpp.pyx` and `primes_python.py`, and then either change the file names or change the naming convention.

It seems that `primes_cpp_c.pyx` / `primes_cpp_cy.pyx`  or `primes_python_p.py` / `primes_python_py.py` is not very nice .. although if you look from the other side, these are internal file names that are not visible to readers of the documentation.

Another idea is to use the `_pure` suffix for apparently pure python, and not use the prefix for the `cdef` syntax.

The good thing about this idea is that in order to comply with the new file naming convention, the documentation does not have to be changed, only to add files with pure python.

The possible exception is the pure python docks, well ... we don't need to add anything there, so I think this is a winning strategy.

> although if you look from the other side, these are internal file names that are not visible to readers of the documentation.

No, I'm wrong, we name the files in the documentation, exactly as I showed [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859157263)

If I also use

> [code tabs](https://sphinx-tabs.readthedocs.io/en/latest/#code-tabs) extension

then I don't even know whether to leave the file names :)

Using `caption`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618473-7cdd7180-ca6f-11eb-9013-f51f20d1cf7e.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618492-87980680-ca6f-11eb-9b34-e3d6c1c5782b.png)

Using `file`

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618678-dd6cae80-ca6f-11eb-88af-e38f52372115.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618697-e9f10700-ca6f-11eb-9b93-3aef5047a1e6.png)

Without filenames

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618854-3c322800-ca70-11eb-88c3-df3f16527aa8.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121618879-46542680-ca70-11eb-90db-d99d5e4900b0.png)

It seems to me that if you embed those tabs so often, they will take up a lot of screen space. Also, there is a good example of tabs from the [opencv docs](https://docs.opencv.org/master/da/d6a/tutorial_trackbar.html).
[Alternative option](https://sublime-and-sphinx-guide.readthedocs.io/en/latest/code_blocks.html#code-examples-in-multiple-languages) to sphinx-tabs, unfortunately almost dead.

What to do? Follow files or code snippets in docs, for example:

- [primes](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/cython_tutorial.html)
  In file - `# The current number of elements in p.`
  In comment - `# The number of elements in p`
  In file - `# Let's return the result in a python list:`
  In comment - `# Let's put the result in a python list:`

In any case, at the moment I will choose the most appropriate and meaningful ones.

My suggestion above to use tabs complicates the problem. Perhaps start with creating content without trying to format with tabs (which is just a presentation issue), and we can iterate on that part of it later.
To me the caption+tabs version looks good. Although I agree with Matti that we can improve the formatting later so it doesn't have to be perfect now.

Now it would be good to set a standard by which subsequent changes will be made. I will share my thoughts on this after I have translated the first page. I think they will be the beginning of the standard.
@0dminnimda sounds good

finally something that i'm more fine with.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121722531-3aa74500-caee-11eb-9918-9434593d8dbc.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121722554-4135bc80-caee-11eb-8b4e-355aa8ba8212.png)
No unnecessary indentation, and I think a nicer selection.
How and where do file tests come from the documentation, more specifically, from the examples directory?

> How and where do file tests come from the documentation, more specifically, from the examples directory?

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/3e7aa76b8957e2347f3cb9dfc077897b65c5d194/runtests.py#L2626-L2634

All Cython/Python files in the examples directory end up compiled. You can run individual tests on your PC with `python3 runtests.py primes` (for example)

Is that what you're asking?
runtests.py automatically looks in the examples directory and finds the files. If you create the files then they will be tested.

> Maybe with suffixes like _cy and _py in the file name for the two syntax variants?

I just remembered that there already is a naming convention for test file name prefixes. If a test file is called `sometest.pyx`, then any file called `sometest_*` will be copied over for the test as a potential test dependency. So that would lead to unnecessary copying. Although we could probably disable the copying for the "examples" directory all together.

Too many ways to do one thing…

> If a test file is called `sometest.pyx`, then any file called `sometest_*` will be copied over for the test as a potential test dependency

I think this is exactly what we need, because, in theory, these files should implement the same functionality.

> Although we could probably disable the copying for the "examples" directory all together.

What for? All versions of the files in the documentation must be correct. And we shouldn't rely on all of them to be manually checked.

> runtests.py automatically looks in the examples directory and finds the files. If you create the files then they will be tested.

Does the test only check if it is compileable? No functionality checks?

The question is, should we include and show in the documentation `import cython` in every pure python file?
I think that it is not necessary to show this, because of this, the code for cython and pure python will always be shifted, and the comparison is more difficult, it also does not carry a lot of information, but it takes up space, moreover, we already indicate in the preface about this

Because if you don't add this, then, of course, the tests fail "undeclared name not builtin: cython"

I see two ways out:
1) add it to all files, but do not show it in the documentation, cutting off with `lines`, but then all other links to parts of the code, like "something important on line 5" will turn into a very unpleasant task, since in the documentation you will have to write something like `: lines: 7`, i.e. all lines will be displaced ..
 2) separately handle tests with files ending in "_pure.py", Including cython in the namespace.

It seems easier and better to do the second
It would be good to solve it as soon as possible, because it depends on how the solution to the issue will develop further. Well, the transition from one to another is also difficult.

> The question is, should we include and show in the documentation import cython in every pure python file?

I think we should include it if it's needed. It makes sure the examples are "complete". And people are likely to skip the preface then ask why the code doesn't work.

Okay, then next question. There are two options for presenting code: 1) that shows the differences when compared 2) normal code with no extra blank lines.

The first option makes it easier to rewrite and add some code (since the lines in both versions are usually the same and easier to refer to), but at the same time it can sometimes look a little ridiculous because of all these empty lines. The downside of the second approach: to refer to lines from a file, you will need to use very different lines for each version.

1:
![ezgif com-gif-maker](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121779045-6e43a700-cba2-11eb-97b9-094a7b772d53.gif)

2:
![ezgif com-gif-maker (4)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121779186-135e7f80-cba3-11eb-8cf5-97867c2c8267.gif)
 
We can also experiment with highlighting new lines.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121779333-ca5afb00-cba3-11eb-8e98-00fde5b2c6ac.png)

Since [this](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860061251) directly affects the appearance of the documentation, I need the opinions of @scoder, @da-woods and others, who can say something, maybe @mattip or @Bluenix2 ?

> The good thing about this idea [adding a `_pure` file name suffix] is that in order to comply with the new file naming convention, the documentation does not have to be changed, only to add files with pure python.

When considering a change, you should always think back from the future. In a future world, where Python type annotations are established, new Python users learn them as part of the language, and Cython employs them for adapting code to data types – will it still be a good idea to have a `_pure` suffix for the files that use that syntax? I think not.

It's like the question whether code that needs to adapt to Py2/Py3 should base its decisions on a flag `IS_PY2` or `IS_PY3`. Once Py4 comes out, `IS_PY3` will probably be misleading. `IS_PY2` will never be.

If we add a marker to the file names, then I suggest doing it either for both variants or for the Cython syntax variant.

Seeing the file names in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859200861, I think it's a good way to help readers find them. The caption variant looks good. And it makes we wonder if distinguishing the files by file extension is really so bad. If we show the file names, then the extension rather seems the obvious way to indicate what syntax is in use.

https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860061251
I prefer 1), with aligned code.

I think it's a nice additional feature if you can switch between the two syntax variants and see the differences immediately. And a couple of additional blank lines should rarely become unbearable.

One annoyance could be the `import cython` at the top, which always occupies two lines that the Cython syntax version can never use. I could live with leaving that out. It shouldn't come as a surprise to Python users that a module needs to be imported before it can be used.

https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859973066
I would also prefer simply adding `import cython` to all `.py` example files *automatically* in `runtests.py`.
(sorry for being unclear in my initial comment)

answering [comment](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860066040)

I also thought not to include `import cython` in every file, here are related comments [1](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859973066) and [2](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859998568)

> [#4187 (comment)](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860061251)
> I prefer 1), with aligned code.

Yeah - I agree. I don't think it's *always* necessary that the two versions line up but it does look quite nice on the gif. So do it where possible.

BTW, there's also [Sybil](https://sybil.readthedocs.io/en/latest/). Adding Cython support to it seems easy (I've started an initial PR) and would allow us to test examples directly in the documentation, not just in files. Not saying that we should do it (it requires a bit of care to keep the code snippets compilable), but it's an option.

> do it where possible.

So far, I have all the code (2 pieces) that I translated could be aligned.
And I'm sure that this can be done with all the examples, it's just a matter of adding blank lines and, perhaps, spreading the code across several lines, like
```python
func_name (arg1, arg2)
```
->
```python
func_name(
    arg1,
    arg2
)
```
or 
```python
func_name(arg1,
          arg2)
```
@scoder if necessary, I could open a issue with [this content](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860066535).

> Seeing the file names in [#4187 (comment)](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-859200861), I think it's a good way to help readers find them.

Then the question arises: should the file names be added to each file insert? In general, this is very useful, where we refer to different files, for example, in a tutorial that compares the speed of a compiled example and regular code. Another thing is that, occasionally, the code represents a modified version of another code, therefore it is necessary to add some additional pointers, like "let's create a new version of the file called XX".

Another question, what do you mean by "help readers find them (files)"? Find files on the documentation page?

> > would also prefer simply adding `import cython` to all `.py` example files _automatically_ in `runtests.py`
> 
> @scoder that's wonderful! The only thing is that there are several thousand lines in the `runtests.py` and I have no idea how this functionality can be added ..

I think this is something that you could leave for someone else to do. Not everything needs to be perfect when you create the pull request (there's plenty of time for other people to help fix things)

> Another question, what do you mean by "help readers find them (files)"? Find files on the documentation page?

They could look inside the cython/docs/ directory on their PC, or find the file on github. Having the name just helps the reads know what to look for.

> I think this is something that you could leave for someone else to do. Not everything needs to be perfect when you create the pull request (there's plenty of time for other people to help fix things)

Then it is definitely necessary for someone to create an issue, thereby making it public, and not just leaving it in comments.

> Not everything needs to be perfect when you create the pull request

Sure, but who doesn't want everything to be perfect? ;)

> And it makes we wonder if distinguishing the files by file extension is really so bad. If we show the file names, then the extension rather seems the obvious way to indicate what syntax is in use.

The problem with the approach, if we have code that, for example, uses c ++ vector, as shown in the tutorial, then this code will not work with python, and therefore will be put in a file with the ending "_pure.pyx", and not "_pure.py " as if the code is also python-compatible. + also a warning about this in the documentation

How does the tests work, in the sense that some .py files are checked for compilation, while all .py files are also checked for being able to run with python?
As far as I understand, if there is a cython import in the ".py" file, then this file is also tested for compilation, is that right?
If yes, then "_pure" will help us in some additional cases, since we do not write `import cython` in _pure files.

> If yes, then "_pure" will help us in some additional cases, since we do not write import cython in _pure files.

Therefore, we definitely need a suffix specifically for files with code using pure python.
It is optional to create a suffix for the сython version, but it seems to be superfluous.
What do you think of this @scoder?

When you show the difference with the gif like this [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860061251) it looks perfect when they align. But in most cases you're actually not comparing the different 'styles', you're using one of them and only looking at that one. Without the context of the other 'style', the one with loads of spaces make no sense.

I say we have it like the option 2. Option 1 is perfect whenever we're comparing between the two, but we're not doing that in 95% of examples.

> I say we have it like the option 2. Option 1 is perfect whenever we're comparing between the two, but we're not doing that in 95% of examples.

It seems to me that with such a nice comparison, adding a few extra lines is a small price we can pay.
But of course, if the user has never used the comparison, this may seem strange..

It also hurts maintainability, albeit not much, it's still something to weigh in.

Also @scoder I can't find the comment but I think you mentioned that using the file extensions to differentiate wouldn't actually be impossible. In my opinion, this would be the very very best option.

> In my opinion, this would be the very very best option.

How would you then be able to distinguish between a cython version and a version that is written in pure python, but cannot run in it because of `cimports`?
[example](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860081193)

There is an option to use `.pxd`, but this does not always help + looks worse than one file with `cimports`

> > If a test file is called `sometest.pyx`, then any file called `sometest_*` will be copied over for the test as a potential test dependency
>
> I think this is exactly what we need, because, in theory, these files should implement the same functionality.

That's not what I meant. They will only be copied over, needlessly, and not run. They will eventually get their own test run, separately, but copying them into the scope of the other test is useless.

> > In my opinion, this would be the very very best option.
> 
> How would you then be able to distinguish between a cython version and a version that is written in pure python, but cannot run in it because of `cimports`?
> [example](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860081193)

Let's try to stick with *only* different extensions for the two versions (.py/.pyx), and see where that gets us. We can solve problems that we run into when we run into them.

Regarding cimports, in the worst case, we can grep the .py versions of the test files for `cython.cimports.` and skip the pure Python run if we find it. Or we can install fake objects in `sys.modules` to make the Python import succeed, like I did for `cython.cimports.libc.math` (which is just mapped to Python's `math` module in `Shadow.py`). I'm confident that this will turn out to be an easy problem.

> How does the tests work, in the sense that some .py files are checked for compilation, while all .py files are also checked for being able to run with python?

The test files in `tests/examples/` are only compiled, not run. So are the tests in `tests/compile/`. The tests in `tests/run/` get compiled and executed.

If there is anything we need to special-case about tests, it's usually done with tags (e.g. `# tag: warning` for tests that produce certain compiler warnings).

We are free to decide how we want to deal with `.py` files under `tests/examples/`. I doubt that it makes much sense to run many of them in Python. But some kind of Python syntax checking (besides Cython compilation) would be nice to have. So why not just pass them through Python and see if there are any test constructs that we need to work around?
I've updated the ticket description with what I think should be done (or tried, to get us started).

> but copying them into the scope of the other test is useless.

Now I understand, I absolutely agree.

> We can solve problems that we run into when we run into them.

I've already run into one. [Here](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/cython_tutorial.html#primes-with-c)
I solved it [this way](https://github.com/0dminnimda/cython/blob/master/docs/examples/tutorial/cython_tutorial/primes_cpp_pure.pyx)
It, of course, does not run through python.

This is just an example of what can happen.

> It, of course, does not run through python.

It could, if we added an arbitrary `cython.cimports.libcpp.vector` to `sys.modules`. We could do that in `runtests.py`. Parse the example file, add fake objects for any `cython.cimports....` names that we find.

Note that I'm not talking about actually running the code. If importing the test module in Python works, that's already a really good start.

> It, of course, does not run through python.

And what worries me is that it also doesn't pass all the tests of `py -3.9 runtests.py primes` in case I rename `primes_cpp_pure.pyx` to `primes_cpp_pure.py`
Here the problem arises that the name `primes_cpp.pyx`, and `primes_cpp.py` will not pass tests, where failures are "undeclared name not builtin: cython".

> Here the problem arises that the name primes_cpp.pyx, and primes_cpp.py will not pass tests, where failures are "undeclared name not builtin: cython".

Why is that? There is an `import cython` in the module – why would it be undeclared?

Another convention: if we use `distutils` or something similar that is in the comments on the first lines of the file, then we include `import cython`.

The argument why this should be included is this: if we use things like `distutils`, then they are expected to be on the first lines, after which the imports should go, and the rest of the files `import cython` seem to be hidden above, when in these, if do not write an import, then at first glance it seems that it is not needed, and this is confusing.

> Another convention: if we use distutils or something similar that is in the comments on the first lines of the file, then we include `import cython`.

Seems reasonable. If we have the space to set directives, we probably also have the space to `import cython`.

> Why is that? There is an `import cython` in the module – why would it be undeclared?

I don't know, but that's what the test results say.

> > Why is that? There is an `import cython` in the module – why would it be undeclared?
> 
> I don't know, but that's what the test results say.

Did you mean `primes_cpp.py` or `primes_pure.py` ? Because the latter really lacks the `import cython`.

I think we can generally keep the `import cython` in code examples that feel "long enough" to have it. I added that to the ticket description.

Apparently, the first time I saw this error, we had not yet agreed that `import cython` should be automatically added by tests, and then I got confused.

In general, everything is ok, if I, wherever necessary, add `import cython` and rename `primes_cpp_pure.py` to `primes_cpp.py`!
(if i do not rename, then the error appears 
`FileNotFoundError: path\to\cython\docs\examples\tutorial\cython_tutorial\primes_cpp_pure.pyx`)

> I think we can generally keep the `import cython` in code examples that feel "long enough" to have it

1) I think it's worth making it a little more specific.
2) It seems to me that the import should not be added if it is the beginning of the code, and there is nothing above it. In such a case, we will need to add additional blank lines to the beginning of the file, which does not look very nice.

Hooray! Finally, the PR #4226 is ready to be reviewed and judged by everyone involved!
I invite you, @scoder, @Bluenix2, @da-woods, @mattip, @TeamSpen210, @goldenrockefeller, to look at the results!

P.S. Sorry to send out massive notifications there, but it seems to me that since you were interested in the issue, you should know about PR.

Some conventions, not mentioned in the ticket, that I used to Pythonise the Basic Tutorial:  
1) Now (with my PR) to include a paragraph about different versions of the code, you need to write:
```rst
.. include::
    ../two-syntax-variants-used
```
at the beginning of the file

2) In order to refer to some lines of code, we use `literalinclude lines`, as described here #4222, more specifically
```rst
.. literalinclude:: <path-to-file>
    :lines: <needed lines>
    :dedent:
    :lineno-start: <first line index>
```
The order of the `lines, dedent and lineno-start` after `literalinclude` is not important, but should best be kept in the order above.
Also for discussion: `lineno-start: <first line index>`
Although I am sure that there is nothing wrong with this, rather, it is more convenient for the reader, constantly not flipping through and looking at what lines are said in the documentation.

With lineno-start:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121790268-63126a80-cbe6-11eb-9489-3d2002bcb62a.png)

Without:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/52697657/121790285-84735680-cbe6-11eb-9d7c-b8c8c3350b17.png)

3) The name of a file whose content is to be shown immediately below should use `literalinclude caption` instead of `file`:
```rst
:file:`<filename>`:
.. literalinclude:: <path-to-file>
    :linenos:
```
->
```rst
.. literalinclude:: <path-to-file>
    :linenos:
    :caption: <filename>
```

4) If `cimports` are used then first try to find and use, the object? from python, with the same functionality (i.e. the same methods, fields, etc.), and use it in place of what is imported with `cimports`, if there is no such object, then just use what is in `cimports` and add a warning for pure python mode only. To include warning to rst:
```rst
.. include::
    ../cimport-warning
```

5) Example for "present both in tabs to make it easy to switch between them" from ticket:
```rst
.. tabs::
    .. group-tab:: Pure Python

        .. literalinclude:: <path-to-file>
            :linenos:

    .. group-tab:: Cython

        .. literalinclude:: <path-to-other-file>
            :linenos:
```

6) Tip: first make sure the new Pythonised code works and passes all tests, then add to the documentation!
@scoder work for you to add [those](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860123077) that you agree with
@0dminnimda, I've changed some of your proposed texts in your comment to what I hope is a bit clearer. Please approve or comment.
@scoder I have corrected the ambiguous phrase (in 2) + confirm your changes.
Also, since we have established an agreement on the 4th, in the near future, as I said, I will put it into a file, so that later contributors couldn't have to copy the warning every time.

The only question  about 4 is, doesn't "native" library exclude the use of `.pyd`/`.so` (cython compiled code)? If it's not, then everything's fine.
This is perhaps a bit of a silly question, but I have to clarify this.

Truth be told, we maybe would like to reduce the technicality of the phrase in that place, maybe just replace or remove "native". It's seems little to mutch details for regular user, that maybe sees cython and this document for the first time.

> The only question about 4 is, doesn't "native" library exclude the use of `.pyd`/`.so` (cython compiled code)? If it's not, then everything's fine.

I used "native" in the sense of "native code, not Python code". Other Cython modules may not be as much of a problem as native libraries and non-Cython extension modules, since there's a higher chance for them to be made from .py files that would also work in Python.

I'm open for improvements, but I'm not sure if removing "native" would make it clearer.

> Other Cython modules may not be as much of a problem as native libraries and non-Cython extension modules, since there's a higher chance for them to be made from .py files that would also work in Python.

In my understanding, this warning should appear wherever it is used `cimport` and where no python alternative was found. Thus, this warning should cover, preferably all cases, including the import of modules generated by cython.

> I used "native" in the sense of "native code, not Python code"

Well, at the very least, it would be very good to get rid of possible misunderstandings.

And I think I know what will help - a link to an article that explains this concept. For example [this](https://searchapparchitecture.techtarget.com/definition/native-code).

And then it would be more than enough.

@scoder if you can think of better source than I proposed you can make your suggestions!

> And I think I know what will help - a link to an article that explains this concept. For example [this](https://searchapparchitecture.techtarget.com/definition/native-code).

To me, a link feels like it blows up the concept to way more than is intended.

What about "native (non-Python) library"? Is that clear enough?

EDIT: to clarify: the intention of this word "native" is to make things _clearer_ and _less_ ambiguous. Not to introduce any concept. If the word requires a link to explain itself, then it's doesn't match that intention.

> What about "native (non-Python) library"?

@scoder Hmm, I think this is the *minimum* amount of information that is sufficient for understanding.
Well, let's dwell on this option.

In this case, wait until I move the warning into a separate file and we add a simple `include` to the list of conventions.
In general, I can already set the lines that will be required for inclusion, and then add this to the PR, so now I will edit my comment.
[done](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860123077)

@scoder  Now the warning looks like this:
```rst
.. warning::

    This code uses an external native (non-Python) library through a ``cimport``.
    Cython compilation enables this, but there is no support for this from
    plain Python. Trying to run this code from Python (without compilation)
    will fail when accessing the external library.
    This is described in more detail in :ref:`calling-c-functions`.
```
no more changes than added "(non-Python)"

> @scoder Now the warning looks like this:
> 
> ```
> .. warning::
> 
>     This code uses an external native (non-Python) library through a ``cimport``.
>     Cython compilation enables this, but there is no support for this from
>     plain Python. Trying to run this code from Python (without compilation)
>     will fail when accessing the external library.
>     This is described in more detail in :ref:`calling-c-functions`.
> ```
> 
> no more changes than added "(non-Python)"

pushed [here](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4226/commits/b4233aebeee8e3164ccce338bbafe27620722596)
@scoder If you have no further comments, then the [comment](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860123077) is final.

> @scoder If you have no further comments, then the [comment](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/4187#issuecomment-860123077) is final.

Looks good. I've linked to it from this ticket.

> 1. Grab a documentation page and duplicate the code examples, putting the Pure Python variant _before_ the `cdef` variant.



> Example:
> 
> ```cython
> cdef int add1(int x) except -1:
>     return x + 1
> ```
> 
> should become
> 
> ```cython
> @cython.exceptval(-1)
> def add1(x: cython.int):
>     return x + 1
> 
> cdef int add1(int x) except -1:
>     return x + 1
> ```

Our current process is a little different, and it would be nice to reflect this in the ticket. We create a file with the same name, but with the `.py` extension and write the pure python version into it.

> 2\. Put the (proposed) following paragraph near the top of the page to show a reference to `import cython` and briefly explain the difference between the two syntax variants:
> 
> ```
> This page uses two different syntax variants: the Cython specific ``cdef`` syntax
> and static Cython type declarations in :ref:`pure Python code <pep484_type_annotations>`,
> following `PEP-484 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/>`_ type hints.
> To make good use of the latter, including C data types etc., you need
> the special ``cython`` module, which you can import with
> 
> .. code-block: python
> 
>       import cython
> 
> in the Python module that you want to compile.
> ```

And the same thing I want to say about this part, as I showed in my comment with conventions:



> 1. to include a paragraph about different versions of the code, you need to write:
> 
> ```
> .. include::
>     ../two-syntax-variants-used
> ```

> This page uses two different syntax variants: the Cython specific ``cdef`` syntax
> and static Cython type declarations in :ref:`pure Python code <pep484_type_annotations>`,
> following `PEP-484 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/>`_ type hints.
> To make good use of the latter, including C data types etc., you need
> the special ``cython`` module, which you can import with
> 
> .. code-block: python
> 
>       import cython
> 
> in the Python module that you want to compile.

To be precise, the current text is:
```rst
This page uses two different syntax variants: the Cython specific ``cdef`` syntax
and static Cython type declarations in
:ref:`pure Python code <pep484_type_annotations>`,
following `PEP-484 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/>`_ type hints
and `PEP 526 <https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0526/>`_ variable annotations.
To make good use of the latter, including C data types, etc., you need
the special ``cython`` module, which you can import with

.. code-block:: python

    import cython

in the Python module that you want to compile.
```
[source](https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aff7601737563d476e43e01e20e86071692bec7d/docs/src/two-syntax-variants-used)

Here is a list of documents that use typical cython syntax for code, such as `cdef`.
We must either Pythonize them, or warn about the impossibility of Pythonization. Of course, exceptions are possible.
If you think that I forgot to add some documents, or added some in vain, then write about it.

[EDIT: List of files moved to ticket description]
Thanks. I've moved the checklist of files into the ticket description to make it more visible.

> I've moved the checklist of files into the ticket description to make it more visible.

It should also reflect the fact that someone is working on some document. (of course, this someone should declare that they is working on the document here)

something like 
- [ ] Topic Name (Nickname is working on it)

And also, in an amicable way, if a PR was created for some topic, then it must also be added there.

like
- [ ] Topic Name (#Number_1)
- [X] Topic Name (#Number_2)
 
The presence of a PR overwrites that someone is working on a document
Therefore, it would be nice if @scoder add #4226 to the basic tutorial.

> Therefore, it would be nice if @scoder add #4226 to the basic tutorial.

Done.

> It should also reflect the fact that someone is working on some document. (of course, this someone should declare that they is working on the document here)

Easiest is probably done opening draft PRs to claim such documents, explaining the scope.

> It should also reflect the fact that someone is working on some document. (of course, this someone should declare that he is working on the document here)

> And also, in an amicable way, if a PR was created for some topic, then it must also be added there.

> The presence of a PR-a overwrites that someone is working on a document

Actually .. we can use the [github projects](https://github.com/features/project-management/) ([here](https://github.com/cython/cython/projects)) for this, although there is no special need for this.
It's kind of a kanban, and it fits well for things like our list.

> Easiest is probably done opening draft PRs to claim such documents, explaining the scope.

If we want people to follow this, then this must be reflected in the ticket.

But I don't really like this idea, because if you say that you are working on something, this does not oblige you to do a PR as a result, although this is very desirable. I think the creation of a draft PR is, as it seems, a kind of statement that the changes will definitely be presented.

But, of course, everyone has their own understanding, and if we are not worried about the possibility of opening draft PR-s, which may never be finished, then this option can also can be taken as an agreement.

On the other hand, we can leave the option to make less public statements by simply commenting on this issue mentioning scoder.

Yes, I understand that since there are much fewer PRs than comments in this issue, it will be easier to track new ones, but it seems to me that this argument is not so strong.

By the way, the next thing I will try to work on is "Extension types (aka. cdef classes)"
@scoder You can add this to the list.

> By the way, the next thing I will try to work on is "Extension types (aka. cdef classes)"
> @scoder You can add this to the list.

@scoder now you can add this PR to the list
like this: "Extension types (aka. cdef classes) (#4232)"
The annotations dictionary is generated *once* at the point the module is imported. It's barely overhead. Don't worry about it. It isn't worth mentioning

> It's barely overhead. Don't worry about it. It isn't worth mentioning

It's just that I'm trying to make sure that both versions are as identical as possible as a result of translation.
And since additional code is generated here, this should be mentioned at least somewhere, maybe not in every such document, but only in a document about [pure python](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html).
And it would also be good to resolve [this](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4232#issuecomment-862880630) now.

Another convention: use Shadow.py types instead of cython types where possible. For example `cython.double` -> `float`.
@scoder  What do you think?
Well, #4232 is ready for review.

> Another convention: use Shadow.py types instead of cython types where possible. For example `cython.double` -> `float`.
> @scoder What do you think?

They aren't the same. `int` and `float` are deliberately ignored in annotations because they don't behave like the c-types with the same name. (Python `int` can be infinity large, while Python `float` is stored in a C `double` rather that a C `float`).

It's a bit ugly having to use the Shadow.py types, but there is good reason!

> They aren't the same.

@da-woods Maybe I should have said something other than shadow.py.  I meant type conversion from [here](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/tutorial/pure.html#pep-484-type-annotations)

```python
def func():
    ...

    # Python types shadow Cython types for compatibility reasons
    a: float = 0.54321          # cdef double a = 0.54321
    b: int = 5                  # cdef object b = 5
    c: long = 6                 # cdef object c = 6
    pass
```

> while Python `float` is stored in a C `double` rather that a C `float`

This is what I propose

> They aren't the same.

On the other hand, this discrepancy may confuse some.


> `int` and `float` are deliberately ignored in annotations

If instead of `cython.double` I'll write `float` then during compilation the maximum that changes is annotations in functions.

> > Another convention: use Shadow.py types instead of cython types where possible. For example `cython.double` -> `float`.
> 
> They aren't the same. `int` and `float` are deliberately ignored in annotations because they don't behave like the c-types with the same name. (Python `int` can be infinity large, while Python `float` is stored in a C `double` rather that a C `float`).

`float` is not ignored (IIRC) and is ok to use in the documentation. Note, though, that it can also be confusing to mix, say, `cython.int` and plain `float` in the same example. People might consider this a documentation bug and read over it. Or, worse, send a PR to fix it.

We should try to keep the examples consistent and free of frowns and surprises. They also should serve as good examples for readers how code *should* be written, more than how code *could* be written.


> It's a bit ugly having to use the Shadow.py types, but there is good reason!

Yeah, there is. I would still be happy if we could use the pre-3.0 time to sort out at least a bit of that ugliness. Subtle differences will always lead to unintended code behaviour and bugs for some users out there.
Any thoughts about [this](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4242#issuecomment-879722321)?

> Any thoughts about [this](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4242#issuecomment-879722321)?

I can't see it being helpful to impose limits. Many changes are global text replacements and structural changes.

> > Any thoughts about [this](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4242#issuecomment-879722321)?
> 
> I can't see it being helpful to impose limits. Many changes are global text replacements and structural changes.

Thought is it good to have such big changes as in #4242 ? It's hard for both OPs and reviewers, so i think we should agree on some method of reducing the scope of work, therefore make less mistakes and life little easier.

.. or maybe not ;)

@scoder i would propose to make it like this instead:

* [Getting Started](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/index.html)
  * [x]  [Building Cython code](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/build.html) ([Add pure python to Getting started #4283](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4283))
  * [x]  [Faster code via static typing](https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/quickstart/cythonize.html) ([Add pure python to Getting started #4283](https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/4283))

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: [ENH] Pythonise the documentation!
